quoteFirst: The Nottingham roughs, who were in great force, made an invasion, and drove all back who would not buy Nottingham tickets. Spring, who had provided tickets for the London men, had not yet arrived. At
quoteLast: the men entered the ring――Caunt first, attended by Molyneux the Black and Jem Turner as seconds, Butler having charge of the bottles. Bendigo was attended by Nick Ward and Jack Hannan, Jem Ward and Jem Burn. They shook hands, and tossed for choice of corners.
title:
Pugilistica: The History of British Boxing, Volume 3 (of 3)
Containing Lives of the Most Celebrated Pugilists; Full Reports of Their Battles from Contemporary Newspapers, With Authentic Portraits, Personal Anecdotes, and Sketches of the Principal Patrons of the Prize Ring, Forming a Complete History of the Ring from Fig and Broughton, 1719-40, to the Last Championship Battle Between King and Heenan, in December 1863
author: Miles, Henry Downes, 1806-1889

quoteFirst: “There!” said Penrod, returning from performing this errand for the fourth time. “It's
quoteLast: , and I'm not goin' in to look at that ole clock again if I haf to die for it! I never heard anybody make such a fuss in my life, and I'm gettin' tired of it. Must think we want to be all night fixin' this cage for our panther! If you ask me to go and see what time it is again, Herman, I'm a-goin' to take back about askin' mamma at five o'clock, and THEN where'll you be?”
title: Penrod and Sam
author: Tarkington, Booth, 1869-1946

quoteFirst: At ten minutes past three the clock and the camera took his photograph--in the twinkling of an eye. At
quoteLast: a second record was made. Before half-past three the man was gone, and the camera winked every ten minutes until six o'clock quite in vain. I came down early this morning and got the roll of negatives.
title: Tales of Fantasy and Fact
author: Matthews, Brander, 1852-1929

quoteFirst: “I jaloused, sirr, that he wadna last oot the day, and Amos here was of the same opinion. The end came at
quoteLast: —I ken the time, for I had just compared my watch with Amos. Ye’ll mind that the Gairmans were beginning a big attack.
title: Mr. Standfast
author: Buchan, John, 1875-1940

quoteFirst: Anderson again refused and again admitted that he would be starved out on the fifteenth. Thereupon Beauregard's aides declared immediate surrender the only possible alternative to a bombardment and signed a note at
quoteLast: giving Anderson formal warning that fire would be opened in an hour.

quoteFirst: You will see by to-day's _Times_ that it _was_ an earthquake that shook me, and that my watch showed exactly the same time as the man's who writes from Blackheath so near us--

quoteLast: of the clock, and there’s light coming on us fast. If so be as the young gentleman knows folks round about here, or happens to live nigh, why shouldn’t he take one of them motor-cars and get away to some decent place? It’ll be better for the poor gentleman than lying here in a house smitten by the Lord.”
title: The Vanished Messenger
author: Oppenheim, E. Phillips (Edward Phillips), 1866-1946

quoteFirst: "But see here," said M. Plantat, "it was the odd hour marked by that clock that struck me. The hands point to
quoteLast: ; yet we know that the countess was fully dressed, when she was struck. Was she up taking tea at three in the morning? It's hardly probable.
title: The Mystery of Orcival

quoteFirst: When the _Oregon_ got to Barbados at
quoteLast: of May 18th, less than six days had elapsed since Cervera quitted Martinique; and the two islands are barely one hundred miles apart. All this, of course, is very much more clear to our present knowledge than it could possibly be to the Spanish Admiral, who probably, and not unnaturally, thought it far better to get his "fleet in being" under the guns of a friendly port than to hazard it on what might prove a wild-goose chase; for, after all, Captain Clark might not have gone to Barbados.
title: Lessons of the war with Spain and other articles
author: Mahan, A. T. (Alfred Thayer), 1840-1914

quoteLast: . Surely Clare was awake again now. But she would wait another five minutes. She watched the hands--marvelled at the interminable length of a minute, and was drifting off on her favourite speculation as to the essential unreality of time, when simultaneously the grandmother struck the half-hour and she sneezed. She jumped up horrified.
title: Regiment of Women
author: Dane, Clemence, 1888-1965
